asana.description: A fundamental standing pose with feet together, arms at sides, and active engagement of all muscles. Develops concentration, stability, and balanced posture.
Establishes proper alignment, grounding, and body awareness. The foundation for all standing poses.
Establishes proper seated alignment, strengthens the core and back muscles, and improves posture. Foundation for seated poses.
A neutral position on hands and knees with a flat back. Foundation for cat-cow, bird dog, and transitions like Downward Dog.
Builds heat and strength in the legs, glutes, and core. Challenges endurance and focus.
Strengthens legs and core, stretches hip flexors. Challenges balance with back knee lifted.
Deep twisting pose that combines the leg strength of Crescent Lunge with a powerful spinal rotation. Improves balance, digestion, and detoxification while stretching hips and shoulders.
Deeply stretches the side body, opens hips and chest, and strengthens legs. Builds stamina.
Standing forward fold with hands placed under the feet (palms up). Deeply stretches hamstrings, calves, and wrists.
Challenges balance, stretches hamstrings and hips, and strengthens the standing leg and core.
Forward fold variation from Warrior 1 with hands interlaced behind back. Deeply opens shoulders and hips, promotes surrender.
Creates a side bend and opens the side waist while maintaining Warrior 2 leg stance. Builds strength and grace.
Stretches hamstrings, groins, and hips while opening the chest and shoulders. Improves stability and alignment.
Strengthens legs and core, opens chest and shoulders, stretches hip flexors. Builds stability, focus, and confidence.
Strengthens legs and arms, opens hips and chest. Builds stamina, focus, and determination.
Stretches hamstrings, calves, and back. Calms the mind, relieves stress, and can improve digestion.
Lengthens the spine, stretches hamstrings lightly. Often used as a transition in Sun Salutations to prepare for stepping or jumping back.
Deeply stretches the entire back body (spine, hamstrings, calves). Calms the nervous system, promotes introspection.
Stretches inner thighs, hamstrings, and spine. Calms the mind, relieves mild back tension. Variations include different hand/arm positions.
Advanced standing balance requiring hip flexibility, hamstring length, core strength, and focus. Combines a bind with leg extension.
Variation of Half Moon Pose involving a bind between the top arm and lifted leg. Deeply opens the chest and challenges balance.
Combines balance, strength, flexibility, and focus. Opens the chest and shoulders, stretches the hip flexors and quads.
Improves balance, concentration, and joint stability (ankles, knees, wrists). Stretches shoulders and upper back.
Challenges balance while strengthening legs and core. Opens hips and chest, improves coordination.
Challenges balance and hamstring flexibility. Strengthens the standing leg. A forward fold with one leg extended upwards.
Improves balance, concentration, and stability. Strengthens ankles and legs, opens hips gently.
Balancing pose that strengthens the entire back body, legs, and core. Improves focus, coordination, and posture.
Seated spinal twist energizes the spine, stimulates digestion, and improves spinal mobility. Stretches hips, shoulders, and neck.
Gentle supine twist that releases tension in the spine and back muscles. Promotes relaxation and can aid digestion.
Performed lying on the back, knees drop to one side while gazing opposite. Gentle spinal rotation, releases lower back.
Combines the strength of Chair Pose with a deep spinal twist. Detoxifies organs, builds heat, challenges balance.
Combines a deep twist with a hamstring stretch. Improves balance, aids digestion, strengthens legs and core.

asana.sanskrit: Parsva Balasana / Urdhva Mukha Pasasana variation
asana.description: Gentle twist from Table Top. Releases tension in the upper back, shoulders, and neck.
Seated pose opening the hips and inner thighs. Can be practiced upright or folded forward. Stimulates pelvic region.
Deep squat opening hips, groin, and lower back. Stretches ankles. Grounding and beneficial for digestion and elimination.
Intense hip opener focusing on the external rotation of the front leg hip and stretching the hip flexor of the back leg. Often practiced folding forward (Sleeping Pigeon).
Supine pose opening hips and inner groin. Gently releases lower back and sacrum. Calming and playful.
Deep hip and groin opener, stretches hamstrings, hip flexors, and quads. Can be practiced on hands or forearms.
Stretches hip flexors (psoas) and quadriceps of the back leg. Builds stability. Back knee rests on the ground.
Upright variation of the hip opener, often incorporating a backbend (King Pigeon) or quad stretch. Opens hips and chest.
Restorative supine pose opening hips, inner thighs, and chest gently. Promotes relaxation and stress relief.
Strengthens core, back muscles, and glutes while improving balance and stability. Done from Table Top.
Strongly engages core muscles (abdominals, hip flexors) and strengthens the spine. Improves balance and concentration.

asana.sanskrit: Makara Adho Mukha Svanasana / Phalakasana II
asana.description: Strengthens core, arms, shoulders, and legs. Builds endurance. Body forms a straight line supported on forearms and toes.
Strengthens arms (triceps), shoulders, wrists, and core. A key transitional pose in Vinyasa yoga (Sun Salutations).
Builds full body strength, particularly core, shoulders, arms, and wrists. Improves posture and stability.
Strengthens wrists, arms, shoulders, core (obliques), and legs. Improves balance and coordination.
Strengthens the entire back body, opens chest, shoulders, and hip flexors. Stimulates abdominal organs and improves posture.
Gentle backbend opening chest and shoulders, strengthening glutes, hamstrings, and back. Calming yet energizing.
Deep backbend opening the entire front body (chest, abdomen, hip flexors, quads). Energizing and emotionally releasing.
Gentle backbend strengthening the spine, arms, and glutes. Opens chest and shoulders. Foundational backbend.
Performed on hands and knees, dropping the belly, lifting chest and gaze. Gently stretches front torso and neck. Paired with Cat Pose.
Opens chest, throat, and shoulders. Stretches front of neck and hip flexors (psoas). Often used as a counterpose to Shoulder Stand.
Strengthens the entire back body (spine, glutes, hamstrings). Improves posture and prepares for deeper backbends.
Stronger backbend than Cobra, opening chest and shoulders while strengthening arms, wrists, and spine. Thighs and knees lift off the floor.
Deep backbend opening the entire front body. Strengthens arms, legs, spine, and abdomen. Highly energizing.
Exuberant backbend and heart opener, entered from Side Plank or Downward Dog. Builds strength, flexibility, and freedom.
Fundamental arm balance building strength in arms, wrists, and core. Improves focus, balance, and confidence.
Strengthens shoulders, arms, and core while stretching hamstrings and opening shoulders. Preparation for forearm stand and headstand.
Full body stretch and strengthener. Lengthens spine, opens shoulders, stretches hamstrings and calves, builds arm strength. Mild inversion.
Advanced arm balance requiring significant core, arm, and wrist strength, plus hamstring and hip flexibility.
Advanced arm balance combining hip opening (like Pigeon Pose) with arm strength and balance.
Full inversion known as the "king" of poses. Improves circulation, balance, focus, and core strength. Requires proper instruction.
Advanced arm balance strengthening wrists, forearms, and core. Improves digestion through abdominal pressure.
Inversion stretching the spine, shoulders, and back of legs. Calms the nervous system, stimulates thyroid.
Full inversion known as the "queen" of poses. Calms nervous system, stimulates thyroid and parathyroid glands, improves circulation.
Variation of Downward Dog lifting one leg. Opens hips, strengthens shoulders and core, prepares for transitions.
Performed on hands and knees, rounding the spine upward, tucking chin to chest. Stretches back torso and neck. Paired with Cow Pose.
Variation of Low Lunge with arms extended overhead, often with a gentle backbend. Opens chest and shoulders, deepens hip flexor stretch.
Comfortable cross-legged seated position for meditation, pranayama, or centering. Promotes calm and hip opening over time.
Kneeling side stretch opening the side body, shoulders, hamstrings, and hips. Improves flexibility along the intercostal muscles.
Kneeling pose stretching thighs, knees, and ankles. Improves posture and digestion. Can be used for meditation.
Relaxed variation of Forward Fold with bent knees, soft spine, and loose arms. Releases tension in spine, shoulders, and hamstrings. Calms the nervous system.
Resting pose gently stretching hips, thighs, ankles, and back. Calms the mind and nervous system. Promotes release and surrender.
Final relaxation pose. Allows the body and mind to integrate the benefits of the practice. Promotes deep rest and rejuvenation.
